title: Henri Lavedan
text:
Henri Léon Emile Lavedan (9 April 1859 – 4 September 1940), French <a href="dramatist">dramatist</a> and <a href="man%20of%20letters">man of letters</a>, was born at <a href="Orl%C3%A9ans">Orléans</a>, the son of , a well-known Catholic and <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a> journalist.
Lavedan contributed to various Parisian papers a series of witty tales and dialogues of Parisian life, many of which were collected in volume form. In 1891 he produced at the <a href="Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre%20Fran%C3%A7ais">Théâtre Français</a> "Une Famille", followed at the <a href="Vaudeville">Vaudeville</a> in 1894 by "Le Prince d'Aurec", a satire on the nobility, afterward renamed "Les Descendants".
He had a great success with "Le Duel" (<a href="Com%C3%A9die-Fran%C3%A7aise">Comédie-Française</a> 1905), a powerful psychological study of the relations of two brothers, which was turned into a movie--"<a href="The%20Duel%20%281939%20film%29">The Duel</a>"—on which he was a co-writer. It was translated into English by <a href="Louis%20N.%20Parker">Louis N. Parker</a> and performed in New York in 1906 at the <a href="Hudson%20Theatre">Hudson Theatre</a>.
Lavedan was admitted to the <a href="Acad%C3%A9mie%20fran%C3%A7aise">Académie française</a> in 1898.
